review_title: A good start in the nonprofit world

review_title: great job but too much pressure
pros: everyone is very passionate about the organization
cons: very fast-paced and intense, and very hard to grow into the role unless you already know about the job

review_title: If you are hard-working, the job can be rewarding . But verify your paychecks against your hours
pros: Festival tickets, fun staff training days, public acknowledgement for good work, good work incentives (mini prizes) and team building exercises were fantastic. The social aspects were brilliant. The parties were fun and there were occasionally national gatherings of fundraisers organised in a ceremony at head office, to present awards and socialise. Working outside and being paid for it is refreshing, its not so much of a sedentary job. Semi-flexible working hours. Variety of location, getting to discover new places in your given region.
cons:
Low tolerance to failure (workers can be put on "probation" before being fired). High turnover of fundraisers means group cohesion can be thrown off. The daunting feeling of not having achieved enough "sign ups" on a day and the subsequent pressure from above i.e. the team leader (who feels pressure from management). 
Frequent miscalculations of wage by payroll executives. Workers, log your hours and check your pay checks!! 

When I realised, I had already left Greenpeace. 

Lastly, there is very little job security, but this is the nature of fundraising, if you reach targets, you stay and reap the benefits.

pros: Flexible working environment with lot of nice colleagues
cons: Not much room for career progression

- big organisation, so encountered a lot of people who don't understand the cause
- HR did not provide suitable support in times of need

pros: Amazing NGO doing good and very considerate of their employees
cons: Quite a repetitive and draining role

pros: good for environment and interesting people

Collaborative, creative work culture 
Passionate people
cons: There can be a lot of pressure.

review_title: Street Fundraiser - Fun but not sustainable
pros: Excellent team, everyone I worked with including supervisors and fundraising managers were lovely. Positive work, empowering. Fundraising is in-house, training directly from the NGO. My training was at their London Headquarters, vegetarian lunch and travel provided.
cons: Target driven. Though supervisors are supportive, if you don't hit target youre gone. Not a good job if you have bills and rent. Signups vary depending on site and weather. Quiet site and bad weather and you've had  it.

pros: If you care about the environment and want to make a difference in a fun way this can be a great job. you get to work with enthusiastic people. My manager was great.
cons: The organisation only cares about its activists and people that work in the office. Despite their claims, the actions don't show they care about fundraising people at all.

pros: There was none, better off fundraising elsewhere.
cons: Made you work past your home time for free, had to go down to London to stay in a nasty hostel, manager was passive aggressive,  far too much admin, had to write a diary on how your day went, why? Having been in the fundraising industry for 8 years previous, it was a very strange company to work for, they created work out of nothing. No work/life balance. I was even hounded on a Sunday!

pros: Salary of £8 an hour plus bonuses was good
cons:
.Long hours of travel
.Standing in the pouring rain and trying to look happy
.Being threatened and insulted by members of the public on a daily basis
.Constant pressure to meet targets 
.Feeling like I was just conning elderly people into giving away what little money they had

job_title: Door to Door Fundraiser in London, England
pros: so much support given to such a hard role and the people are amazing
cons: prepare to face a lot of rejection and work towards a tight deadline and goals

review_title: A lot of passion for environment, if you eat meat you may feel awkward there
pros: Homely office environment, some dogs allowed!
cons: People who work there are very much white middle-class, so diversity is limited.
longer than specified hours at work
